body:
Thanks! Please use the issue template next time so that we know your mitmproxy version right away.

This still affects master:
```
pathoc -c example.com:80 localhost:8080 'get:/:u"foo\tbar"'
```

This seems to be an urwid issue:
```python
import urwid

txt = urwid.Text(u"Hello\tWorld")
fill = urwid.Filler(txt, 'top')
loop = urwid.MainLoop(fill)
loop.run()
```
Are there any problems with fixing this issue?

We can just change https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/master/mitmproxy/tools/console/flowview.py#L156 to
`[(h + ":", v.encode("unicode_escape")) for (h, v) in conn.headers.items(multi=True)]` or 
`[(h + ":", repr(v)[1:-1]) for (h, v) in conn.headers.items(multi=True)]`

If we use pathoc as @mhils suggested `pathoc -c example.com:80 localhost:8080 'get:/:u"foo\tbar"'`, we will see:
![2018-01-03 17-06-44](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20267977/34525693-813c9c00-f0a8-11e7-9f06-83d62eeed84f.png)

What do you think?

issue.title: Fixing #1833

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
Fix for #1833.
There is also more readable 
`[(h + ":", v.encode("unicode_escape")) for (h, v) in conn.headers.items(multi=True)]`,
 but I thought, that there was no a good reason to change `str` type of second element of tuple to `bytes`.

Applying `pathoc -c example.com:80 localhost:8080 'get:/:u"f\too\tba\tr"'`, we will get:
![screenshot from 2018-01-05 14-59-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20267977/34610289-26962ece-f229-11e7-88a5-2f303a2a9880.png)

issue.title: Fix #1833, clean up common.format_keyvals

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
This is a fix for #1833 with a general cleanup of related functionality. In particular `common.format_keyvals` got a lot of cruft removed and now has at least somewhat better tests. 

Last but not least, I was also able to finally reproduce a bug we previously only hit on appveyor, namely timestamps in our tests that overflow in localtime. Doesn't belong here, but eh.
